channel.title: Interleaved RSS Feed
channel.description: This is an interleaved feed of the most recent entries from each RSS source, skipping any feeds with errors.

item.title: Why China’s Most Can-Do City Is Tired
item.description: Chinese pride and triumphalism have given way to malaise in the post-Covid era.

item.title: What to Know: First Trial in Alleged Coup Plot in Germany to Begin
item.description: Three trials this spring are centered on the Reichsbürger movement. Some of its members say the modern German state is actually a corporation run by shadowy bureaucrats.

item.title: Goldman Sachs has warned its staff about sneaking off to Paris during the Olympics—and leaving the bank to pick up the tab
item.description: “In line with previous Olympic games, we have asked our people to effectively manage their spend and ensure coordination."

item.title: What to Know: First Trial in Alleged Coup Plot in Germany to Begin
item.description: Three trials this spring are centered on the Reichsbürger movement. Some of its members say the modern German state is actually a corporation run by shadowy bureaucrats.

item.title: Middle East Crisis: Blinken Meets With Top Arab Diplomats on Gaza War
item.description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken, in Saudi Arabia, discussed cease-fire talks with officials from Persian Gulf states. He heads to Jordan and Israel next.

item.title: Ryanair's Michael O'Leary, who is up for a $108 million bonus, doesn’t see high CEO pay as a problem: 'Footballers are getting half a million a week'
item.description: Michael O'Leary says that if football players and their managers can get paid in the multi-millions, why not him?

item.title: Delay, Delay, Delay
item.description: How Donald Trump has slowed the cases against him.

item.title: Spain’s Leader Declares He Won’t Quit Over Wife’s Corruption Case
item.description: Prime Minister Pedro Sánchez, a progressive with a reputation as a wily survivor, sought to end days of anxiety over corruption allegations against his wife that he says are a smear.

item.title: EU's unwinnable EV price war: BYD cars 11 times more profitable in Europe than in China
item.description: Only a highly unlikely 50% import tariff would be enough to deter Chinese automakers from Europe, new research finds.

item.title: The Latest Push for a Gaza Pause, and Crackdowns on College Protests
item.description: Plus, a debate about killing owls.

item.title: Israeli Officials Believe I.C.C. Is Preparing Arrest Warrants Over Hamas War
item.description: The officials said they believed that Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and other Israelis could be charged, and that the court was also considering warrants for Hamas leaders.

item.title: McKinsey boss tries to boost staff morale amid layoffs by blasting Eminem, Bob Marley and Chumbawamba
item.description: Global Managing Partner Bob Sternfels told his fellow partners at the mid-April event that McKinsey is expecting a good 2024 after its challenges of the past 18 months.

item.title: Trump 2.0: What a Second Trump Presidency Would Bring
item.description: On the campaign trail, Donald Trump has signaled that a second term would be more radical and vindictive than his first one.

item.title: They Shoot Owls in California, Don’t They?
item.description: An audacious federal plan to protect the spotted owl would eradicate hundreds of thousands of barred owls in the coming years.

item.title: Why Sam Bankman-Fried is turning against A-list FTX boosters—and what could happen to them
item.description: Some of the celebs who took money to tout SBF’s exchange may be in hotter water than others.
